Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Paul Seung Soo Kim of Drexel University to conduct a research project in Mechanical Engineering during the summer of 2013 at the Korea Institute of Science and Technology in Seoul, Republic of Korea. The project title is Fabrication of Light Activated Micro-grippers for Cellular Robots. The host scientist is Dr. JinSeok Kim.
This project develops tweezer-like microscale grippers (~15ìm) composed of photoresponsive materials using a light fabrication technique similar to the one used to develop computer chips. The grippers are being attached onto the fresh-water microorganism, Tetrahymena pyriformis, using magnetic and chemical adhesion. These inorganic attached grippers will be opened and closed with various colors of light. The combined microbe and gripper are controlled as a single microbiorobot with potential uses in biomedical applications and microassembly. The developed platform is anticipated to serve as a prototype for microrobots functionalized with some inorganic actuator.
Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this academic and cultural experience will be promoted and shared through mentoring via various organizations, programs, and symposiums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For eight weeks, research was focused on the control of a microrobot using two types of magnetic fields in various fluid environments. A magnetic robot was controlled in experiments in air, water, and glycerin. The robot was visualized and controlled using a vision feedback system – a camera integrated with a computer that calculates and automates the robot’s direction, position, and trajectory. Two types of magnetic fields controllers were of interest: a Helmholtz system, characterized by a uniform magnetic field, and a Maxwell system, characterized by a non-uniform magnetic field. Each of these systems has its separate advantages. Experiments were conducted using these two types of systems to steer a robot in various patterns. By utilizing a combination of these systems, the robot could be controlled combining the merits of these two systems: fast navigation and lower power consumption. By changing the fluid environment in which this robot operated, the motion of a much smaller robot may be predicted. The advantage to using a larger scale robot in an environment analogous to a robot on a smaller scale is the ease of visualization and control in experiments. Based on results, the hybrid Maxwell and Helmholtz system may be utilized on smaller scale robots with similar performance.

The Intellectual Merit of the research is multidisciplinary, drawing from the fields of microrobotics, control systems, and fluid dynamics with microscale manipulation applications in cell therapy, drug delivery, and microassembly.

The Broader Impacts of this EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language  These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the development of these proposed technologies may be of great benefit for medical applications using microrobots.
